THE SUTRA OF THE RECOLLECTION OF THE NOBLE THREE JEWELS
thams cad mkhyen pa la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
I prostrate to the All-Knowing One.

'di ltar sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das de bzhin gshegs pa dgra bcom pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas rig pa dang zhabs su ldan pa/ bde bar gshegs pa/ 'jig rten mkhyen pa/ skyes bu 'dul pa'i kha lo bsgyur ba/ bla na med pa/ lha dang mi rnams kyi ston pa/ sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das te/

Thus it is: the buddha bhagavat tathāgata arhat saṃyaksaṃbuddha, possessor of insight and its feet, sugata, knower of the world, unsurpassed driver who tames beings, and teacher of gods and men is the buddha bhagavat.
de bzhin gshegs pa de ni bsod nams dag gi rgyu mthun pa/ dge ba'i rtsa ba rnams chud mi za ba/
This tathāgata corresponds to a cause of merits. His roots of virtue do not go to waste.
bzod pa dag gis rab tu brgyan pa/ bsod nams kyi gter rnams kyi gzhi/
He is fully ornamented with all patience. His basis is troves of merit.
dpe byad bzang po rnams kyis spras pa/ mtshan rnams kyi me tog rgyas pa/
The excellent minor signs adorn him. The flowers of the major marks bloom on him.
spyod yul ran par mthun pa/
Perceiving his activity, it being just right, there is harmony.
mthong na mi mthun pa med pa/ dad pas mos pa rnams la mngon par dga' ba/
Seeing him, there is no disharmony. He brings overt joy to those who long through faith.
shes rab zil gyis mi gnon pa/ stobs rnams la brdzi ba med pa/
His prajñā cannot be overpowered. His strengths cannot be challenged.
sems can thams cad kyi ston pa/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi yab/ 'phags pa'i gang zag rnams kyi rgyal po/ mya ngan las 'das pa'i grong khyer du 'gro ba rnams kyi ded dpon/
He is a teacher to all sentient beings, a father to the bodhisatvas, a king to the noble persons, a captain to those who journey to the city of nirvana.
ye shes dpag tu med pa/ spobs pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa/
His wisdom is unfathomable. His knowledgeability is inconceivable.
gsung rnam par dag pa/ dbyangs snyan pa/
His speech is complete purity. His melody is pleasing.
sku byad blta bas chog mi shes pa/ sku mtshungs pa med pa/
One never has enough of viewing the image of his body. His body is unparalleled.
'dod pa dag gis ma gos pa/ gzugs dag gis nye bar ma gos pa/ gzugs med pa dag dang ma 'dres pa/
He is not contaminated by the things of desire. He is very much not contaminated by the things of form. He is not mixed with the things of formlessness.
sdug bsngal las rnam par grol ba/
He is completely liberated from the sufferings.
phung po dag las rab tu rnam par grol ba/ khams rnams dang mi ldan pa/ skye mched rnams bsdams pa/ mdud pa rnams shin tu bcad pa/
He is utterly completely liberated from the skandhas. He does not possess dhātus. His āyatanas are restrained. He has totally cut the knots.
yongs su gdung ba dag las rnam par sgrol ba/ sred pa las grol ba/
He is completely liberated from the torments. He is liberated from craving.
chu bo las brgal ba/ ye shes yongs su rdzogs pa/
He has crossed over the river. His wisdom is totally complete.
'das pa dang*/ ma byon pa dang*/ da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi ye shes la gnas pa/
He abides in the wisdom of the buddha bhagavats who arise in the past, present, and future.
mya ngan las 'das pa la mi gnas pa/ yang dag pa nyid kyi mtha' la gnas pa/ sems can thams cad la gzigs pa'i sa la bzhugs pa ste/
He does not abide in nirvana. He abides in the limit of the authentic itself. He abides on the level of looking upon all sentient beings.
'di dag ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi sku che ba'i yon tan yang dag pa rnams so/ /
These are the true qualities of the greatness of the body of the buddha bhagavat.

dam pa'i chos ni thog mar dge ba/ bar du dge ba/ mtha' mar dge ba/ don bzang po/ tshig 'bru bzang po/ ma 'dres pa/ yongs su rdzogs pa/ yongs su dag pa/ yongs byang ba/ bcom ldan 'das kyis chos legs par gsungs pa/ yang dag par mthong ba/ nad med pa/ dus chad pa med pa/ nye bar gtod pa/ 'di mthong ba la don yod pa/ mkhas pa rnams kyis so sor rang gis rig par bya ba/ bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la legs par ston pa/ nges par 'byung ba/ rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu 'gro bar byed pa/ mi mthun pa med cing*/ 'dus pa dang ldan pa/ brten pa yod pa rgyu ba bcad pa'o/ /

The holy dharma is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good at the end. Its meaning is excellent, its wording is excellent. It is not adulterated, is totally complete, is total purity, is total purification. The bhagavat has taught dharma well. It is authentic sight. It is free from sickness. Its time has no interruption. It brings one in. This is meaningful to see. It is known to the experts through personal self-knowing. The dharma spoken by the bhagavat was well taught for taming. It is renunciation. It causes one to go to complete enlightenment. It is without dishar- mony and it has inclusion. It has reliability. It does end the journey.

theg pa chen po'i dge 'dun ni/ legs par zhugs pa/ rig pa zhugs pa/ drang po zhugs pa/ mthun par zhugs pa/ thal mo sbyar ba'i 'os su gyur pa/ phyag bya ba'i 'os su gyur pa/ bsod nams kyi dpal gyi zhing*/ yon yongs su sbyong ba chen po/ sbyin pa'i gnas su gyur pa/ kun tu yang sbyin pa'i gnas su gyur pa chen po'o/ /

The saṅgha of the great vehicle have entered into good, have entered into insight, have entered into straightness, have entered into harmony. They are worthy of joined palms, they are worthy of prostration. They are a field of the glory of merit. They are great ones thoroughly trained in gifts. They are a place for generosity. They are in all places even a great place for generosity.

A LITTLE EXPLANATION OF THE MEANING OF THE SUTRA OF THE RECOLLECTION OF THE THREE JEWELS
by Jetsun Tāranātha
o swA sti/
oṃ svāsti
sangs rgyas dang chos dang dge 'dun la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
I prostrate to the Buddha, dharma, and saṅgha.
dkon mchog gsum rjes su dran pa'i mdo don cung zad bshad par bya ste/
I will give a little explanation of the meaning of the Sutra of the Recollection of the Three Jewels.

'dir rjes su dran pa zhes pa'i rjes su dran pa'i don ni dngos la yon tan ji ltar yod pa ltar ma nor bar rjes su zhugs pa nyid do/ / de la 'di ni dkar po'i chos mtha' dag gi rtsa bar gyur pa/ yul mchog la dad pa bskyed pa'i ched du yin la/

Recollection as it is used here means to look into the way in which something has good qualities. This recollection, which is the root of positive dharmas in their entirety, is done for the purpose of arousing faith in the supreme objects[32].

dad pa dang mos pa dang gus pa zhes bya ba yang / gnas skabs mang po zhig tu blo'i rigs mtshan nyid shin tu tha dad par yang 'chad cing / gnas skabs gzhan 'ga' zhig tu ni don gcig ming gi rnam grangs su yang byed do/ / 'on kyang skabs 'dir gsum po don gyi gtso bo la gcig par 'gyur zhing cha shas phra mo nas khyab che chung cung zad yod par yang bya'o/ /

The words “faith”, “appreciation[33]”, and “respect” often are used to refer to aspects of mind that are very different in character. However, they are sometimes used as different names for the same thing[34]. In this text, the three terms are used with basically the same meaning, each one presenting a different shade of that basic meaning.

de yang dad pa ni rnam pa gsum ste/ dang ba'i dad pa dang / yid ches pa'i dad pa dang / 'dun pa'i dad pa'o/ / dang po ni/ 'dir dkon mchog gsum gyi yon tan thos nas/ de rnams mchog tu 'dzin cing / mchog tu shes pa dang / de yang yid la dga' ba phun sum tshogs pa mchog dang mtshungs par ldan pa'o/ /

Faith is of three types: admiring, trusting, and aspiring. The first one is that, having heard here of the good qualities of the Three Jewels, they are understood and believed to be supreme and, moreover, there is a joy of mind with it that is complete in every way, a joy that amounts to being supreme[35].

yid ches pa'i dad pa ni/ de bzhin gshegs pa la yon tan de dang de yod par yid ches pa dang / lung gi chos nas ji skad bshad pa la/ don bden cing nges pa'i tshig tu yid ches pa dang / rtogs pa'i chos dang / dge 'dun la yang de dang de'i yon tan dang ldan par yid ches pa dang / don dam pa'i chos 'gog pa'i bden pa yang / skyon thams cad dang bral bar yid ches pa dang / gang skyon thams cad dang bral ba de ni yon tan thams cad dang ldan pa yin te/ gang dang gang gi phan yon dang mi ldan pa de nyid skyon yin pa'i phyir ro/ /

Then, trusting faith[36] is like this. There is trust that the tathāgata has such and such good qualities, trust that the explanations coming from the dharma of authoritative statement are true in meaning and correct in their wording, and trust that the dharma of realization and the saṅgha too have such and such good qualities[37]. There is trust that the superfactual dharma[38] is the truth of cessation and free of all faults, and that that, which is free of all faults, has all good qualities because that which does not have beneficial features is faulty[39].

'dun pa'i dad pa ni/ sangs rgyas dang dge 'dun gyi go 'phang thob par 'dun cing 'dod pa dang / lung gi chos khong du chud par 'dod pa dang / don dam dbyings kyi chos mngon du bya bar 'dod pa dang / rtogs pa'i chos rgyud la skyed par 'dod pa rnams 'dun pa'i dad pa dngos yin la/ rnam grangs tsam du dkon mchog mchod par 'dod pa dang / yon tan sgrags par 'dod pa dang / lung gi chos dar bar 'dod pa la sogs pa yang 'dun pa'i dad pa yin no/ / de dag kyang dang ba dang yid ches pa'i dad pa sngon du song bas ni de ltar yin gyi/ khe'i phyir dang / grags pa 'dod pa dang / 'gran pa'i phyir mchod pa la sogs de rnams 'dod pa ni/ de dang der 'dun pa tsam yin yang dad pa ni ma yin no/ /

Then, for aspiring faith: aspiring and wanting[40] to attain the rank of buddha and saṅgha, wanting to fully absorb the dharma of authoritative statement, wanting to manifest the dharma of the superfactual expanse, and wanting to produce the dharma of realization within the mindstream all are the actual aspiring faith. Those things that must be included with them, such as wanting to make offerings to the Jewels, wanting to broadcast their good qualities, wanting to spread the dharma of authoritative statement, and so on are put with aspiring faith[41]. To take this further, when admiring and trusting faith have been engendered ahead of such activities, those activities are of the faithful kind but, when wanting the things mentioned is joined with offerings, and so on made for profit, fame, or competitive purposes, that is merely aspiration for the things mentioned, not faith in connection with them.

mos pa zhes bya ba ni/ nges pa'i dngos po la nges par 'dzin pa ste/ skabs 'dir ni gang yon tan dang ldan pa dang / gang mi bslu ba de la yon tan dang ldan par shes shing mi bslu bar shes pa ste/ gtso cher yid ches pa'i dad pa yin no/ / yang mngon pa las/ dga' dang gus nyid ngo tsha shes/ / zhes kyang 'byung mod/ skabs 'dir gus pa ni yul de nyid mchog tu shes pa yin pas/ phal cher dang ba'i dad par 'du ba yin/ yang bslab pa la gus pa zhes pa lta bu yid ches pa'i dad pa'i rigs kyang yod la/ de las gzhan gus par sbyor ba zhes pa/ brtson 'grus shugs drag po la bshad pa'ang yod mod skabs 'dir mi sbyar ro/ /

“Appreciation” in general means to see certain qualities in something that does have those qualities. Here, it specifically means to know that something which has good qualities and is not deceptive does have good qualities and is not deceptive[42]. For the most part it is trusting faith, though the Abhidharma also says that it is, “joy, respect, and wonder” and these do indeed accompany it. Here, “respect” means holding up the object as special, so it is mostly contained within admiring faith. Note that the Abhidharma explains a type of trusting faith, which it calls “respect for the trainings”, and mentions “respectful application” in relation to it, which it explains as a “strong perseverance”, but this subject does not apply here[43].

gang dkon mchog gsum la dad pa phun sum tshogs pa dang ldan pa de ni skyabs su 'gro ba len par 'gyur zhing / so so thar pa'i sdom pa len pa dang byang chub tu sems bskyed par yang 'gyur la/ bslab pa gsum dang pha rol tu phyin pa dag la yang 'jug par 'gyur bas/ lam thams cad kyi rtsa ba ni dad pa yin la/ de yang dkon mchog gsum rjes su dran pa la rag las so/ / de la dang por sangs rgyas rjes su dran pa'i dbang du byas nas/

Someone who has a very complete type of faith in the Three Jewels will take up going for refuge, take on the vows of individual emancipation, and also will arouse the enlightenment mind. That person will then engage in the three principal trainings and the pāramitās. Thus, the root of all paths is faith and that in turn only comes about through recollecting the Three Jewels. The recollection is initially done in relation to the Buddha.[44]
