He also sees the ones more even than that, the buddhas and bodhisatvas whose name and family are not concordant, but why mention that when, in the world systems of that sort, the fields in which buddhas arise and bodhisatvas perform the conduct are lesser in number, similar to the sands of an ocean or the sands in the river Ganges and the rarity of gold grains within them.[203]

de'i tshul gyis tshad med ba'i zhing mkha' khyab ma 'dres par gzigs pa de dag tu/ rdzu 'phrul rnam par rol pa gang la gang 'dul gyi sku dang gsung rnam pa thams cad par 'tshar zhang / yid bzhin nor bu'i tshul gyis phan bde'i mdzad pa rtag khyab tu 'jug kyang rnam rtog med par lhun gyis grub pa ni/ 'di ltar phyogs dus kyi shes bya thams cad rang bzhin bden stong du gnas pa de de bzhin mngon du mdzad de/ nam mkha' dang lag mthil mnyam/ skad cig dang bskal pa mnyam nas chos dbyings glo bur gyi dri mas dag pa mngon du gyur ba'i de bzhen gshegs pa ni srid zhi gnyis su med pa mi phyed ye shes rdo rje'i sku/ rdul dang skad cig ma'i chos las 'das pa/ don dam par brjod du med kyang / tha snyad pa'i tshad mas gzhal na skyon kun zad/ yon tan kun rdzogs/ mkhyen brtse nus gsum pha mtha' med pa/ rtag brtan zhi ba g.yung drung gi rang bzhin du grub pa de las ma g.yos bzhin du/ gsang gsum gyi snang ba mi zad pa ni shes bya'i grangs snyed du 'phro bas blos ji tsam phye yang mtha' mi mngon pa nam mkha' 'dom la gzhal ba lta bu yin pas tshad med par shes dgos shing / de'ang sangs rgyas thams cad kyi sgyu 'phrul tshad med pa yang sangs rgyas gcig gi rang bzhin du gnas pa'i tha dad pa'i chos dang / sangs rgyas gcig nyid phyogs dus kun la khyab par gang 'dul gyi rol pa so sor snang ba'i gcig bden gyi mtha' dang bral ba sogs bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i ye shes kyi sku yin la de nyid kyi phyir na sangs rgyas kyi sas bsdus pa'i chos thams cad ma lus pa snang stong mnyam pa nyad kyi ye shes gyi rang bzhin 'ba' zhig yin pas/ sku'i ba spu'i khung bu gcig dang / 'od zer gcig gi+e yon tan kyang nam mkha'i khams khyab pas na rgyal ba rnams kyis phyi ma'i mu mthar thug gi bar du brjod kyang zad pa med pa la nges shes gting nas bskyed par bya ste/ dper na byang chub sems dpa' shugs 'chang gis de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku'i tshad brtag pa dang / mo'u gal gyi bus sangs rgyas kyi gsung gi mtha' brtag pa la sogs pas mtshon te shes par bya'o/ /

Then, in those immeasurable fields which he sees pervasively and without mixup in that manner, his mind shines forth as all the appearances of body and speech done for taming in the displays of miracles for those to be tamed. And, at the same time, in the manner of a wish-fulfilling jewel, he engages perpetually and everywhere in the deeds of benefit and bliss but does so without discursive thought, spontaneously, as follows. All knowables of space and time are present with a nature empty of truth and he has manifested that as it is. The tathāgata who has manifested the dharmadhātu purified of the adventitious stains in which space and the palm of the hand, and an instant and an aeon have been equalized is the wisdom that does not falter from the non-duality of becoming and peace, the vajra kāya, beyond phenomena of atoms and instants, the inexpressible superfactual. He is this inexpressible superfact yet, when evaluated with valid cognizers of the conventional[204], he is all faults exhausted and all good qualities complete; he is knowledge, love, and capacity without endpoint; he exists via a nature of being permanent, steady, peace, svastika[205]. He never wavers from that, yet all the while the inexhaustible appearances of his three secrets[206] permeate as many knowables as there are. Thus, no matter how much rational mind tries to distinguish them, like trying to measure space in fathoms, no end is found, so they have to be understood to be immeasurable. Moreover, the buddhas’ illusions might be immeasurable like this, but the different dharmas are present in one buddha’s nature, and one buddha himself is the inconceivable wisdom kāya that has each one of the individual appearances that are the displays done for taming that pervade all of space and time and which are divorced from the extremes of truth[207]. Because of all that, every single one of all the dharmas included in the buddha level, apparent yet empty, is never anything but the nature of equality wisdom. Thus, the qualities of even one hair pore and one light ray of the body pervade the space element[208] and, based in that, the conquerors continue to speak all the way to the ultimate possible future limit but all for the purpose of generating a deep certainty about this unending state. To illustrate this, there are the examples of bodhisatva Shugchang examining the extent of the tathāgata’s body and Maudgyalyāyana examining the limit of Buddha’s speech, and others. It can be known through such examples.
gnyis pa spyir bstan pa
2. The overview
['di] la/ skye rgu'i ston par gyur pa dang / tshul ji lta bus ston par mdzad pa gnyis/
This has two parts: he is the teacher of the various beings; and how he acts as teacher.
dang po [skye rgu'i ston par gyur pa]
1. He is the teacher of the various beings
['di] la mdor bstan rgyus bshad gnyis/
This has two parts: a summary; and an extensive explanation.
dang po [mdor bstan]/
1. Summary
sems can thams cad kyi ston pa zhes/
He is a teacher to all sentient beings.

phyogs dus ris su ma chad pa'i 'gro ba sems can thams cad la phan bde'i lam bzang snang bar mdzad pa ste/ mdo las/ gti mug mun pa mun nag gis rtag tu/ / sems ni bsgribs par gyur ba'i skye rgu dang / / 'khor ba'i btson rar chud pa rnams gzigs na/ / dang srong dam pa de ni thugs rje skyed/ / ces gsungs pa ltar thugs rje chen pos rtag tu lam ston pa'o/ /

He enacts the appearance of the good path of benefit and ease without bias for every one of the migrator sentient beings throughout time and space. A sutra says, On seeing the various beings whose minds are perpetually Obscured by the gloom of the darkness of delusion And who have entered samsara’s gaol, That holy ṛiṣhi arouses the mind. Thus, the Great Compassionate One perpetually teaches the path.
gnyis pa rgyas bshad
2. Extensive explanation
['di] la/ byang chub sems dpa' rnams kyi yab ces sogs tshigs gsum ste/
There are three lines to this. He is a father to the bodhisatvas.

bla na med pa'i byang chub don du gnyer ba la snying stobs bzlog tu med pa'i byang chub sems dpa' rnams ni/ rgyal ba'i gdung 'dzin pa dang / dam pa'i chos kyi mdzod la dbang ba dang / gdul bya'i lhag ma skyong ba/ bsam mi khyab pa'i ye shes kyi rgyal thabs la dbang bsgyur du rung bas/ 'khor sgyur gyi sras mtshan dang ldan pa lta bu yin pas na de dag gi mtshan du rgyal ba'i sras zhes bya la/ dre rnams kyi yab tu gyur pa ste/ dang po rigs kyi sa bon bskrun pa dang / bar du spang rtogs kyi skyed bsring ba dang / tha mar bcu pa'i sa la chos kyi rgyal por dbang skur bar byed pa po sangs rgyas ni yab ces bya'o/ /

The bodhisatvas, the ones who have a force of determination that does not turn back from seeking unsurpassable enlightenment, the ones who hold the family line of the conquerors, the ones who have mastery over the treasury of the holy dharma and protect beings to be tamed who have been left out, are the ones suitable to be led through to the coronation method of inconceivable wisdom[209]. Accordingly, they can be thought of as “the sons of the ones who govern the retinue” and because of that are given the name “sons of the conquerors”. For these beings the tathāgata first activates their family seed, then during the course of their development causes their abandonment and realization to grow, and finally, on the tenth level, bestows on them the empowerment which enacts their coronation as dharma kings[210]. Thus it is that the tathāgata from his side acts as their “father” and therefore he is called such.

'phags pa'i gang zag dgra bcom pa la sogs pa rnams kyi rgyal po lta bu ste/ gnas brtan shA ri'i bu dang mo'u gal gyi bu chen po lta bu'ang bcom ldan 'das kyis bcas pa'i bslab pa phra mo srog gi phyir yang mi gtong bar bcom ldan 'das chos kyi rgyal po'i bka' la gnas pa kho nas rang lam gyi 'bras bu thob dgos pas na/ 'phags pa'i gang zag rnams kyi rgyal po zhes so/ /

For the noble persons who were the arhats, and so on, the bhagavat was like a king. He stayed together with those like the elder Śhāripūtra and great Maudgalyāyana, staying within his own command, the command of the bhagavat, king of dharma, no more and no less, not discarding the slightest training even at the cost of life specifically so that they could attain the fruition of their own path. Thus, he is a king to the noble persons.[211]

yang sku dngos dang phrin las kyi 'jug pa ji rigs pas 'gro ba rnams lam gyi rten dang / lam dang / lam mthar phyin pa la 'god cing / mthar thug gi byang chub gsum po gang rung gi grong khyer nyams dga' bar phyin par byed cing / 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal gyi rgya mtsho las sgrol bar byed pa la don mthun rnams sgrol ba'i ded dpon lta bu yin pas na/ mya ngan las 'das pa'i grong khyer du 'gro ba rnams kyi ded dpon zhes grong khyer du 'gro bar byed pa rnams kyi ded dpon no//

Further, the actual body with its ways of engagement in appropriate enlightened activity does the job of giving migrators a support; he gives them the support of the path, of setting them on to it, of causing making them follow it, and of making them finalize it. In that way, the tathāgata does the job altogether of making them go joyfully to the city of all three end enlightenments[212]. With that, he does the job of liberating them from samsara’s ocean of suffering, therefore he is like a captain who does the work of liberating like-minded beings. Thus he is a captain to those who journey to the city of nirvana meaning that he is, in that way, a captain who does the work that is involved in getting those beings who are going to the city of nirvana to that city[213].
gnyis pa tshul ji lta bus ston pa
2. How he acts as teacher
['di] la/ thugs kyi mdzad pa dang / gsang ge dang / sku'i mdzad pa gsum/
This has the three parts of: mind activity; speech activity; and body activity.
dang po [thugs kyi mdzad pa]/
1. Mind activity
tshig gnyes las/
This is shown with two phrases.
ye shes dpag tu med pa zhes/
His wisdom is unfathomable.

gdul bya'i don sgrub pa'i thabs kyi gtso bo stobs bcur bzhag pa dang / chos ston pa'i skabs kyi yang dag rig pa bzhir bzhag pa dang / ye shes kyi ngo bo ldog chas phye ba'i ye shes lnga dang / dus gsum la chags thogs med par 'jug pa'i ye shes gsum dang / bsdus na ji lta ji snyed mkhyen pa'i ye shes gnyis dang / de'ang bsdus na rang byung gi ye shes rnam pa thams cad mkhyen pa nyag gcig tu 'du la/ ye shes de ni phyogs dang dus kyis bsdus pa'i shes bya ji snyed pa'i grangs bzhin tu tshad med pa ste/ dpe dang grangs dang gtan tshigs la sogs pas nam yang pha mtha' gzhal mi nus pas blos dpag tu med pa yin pas na/ ye shes dpag tu med pa zhes so/ /

From the standpoint of being the principal method for accomplishing the purposes of those to be tamed, wisdom is defined as the ten strengths, and from the standpoint of showing dharma to those to be tamed, it is defined as the four authentic insights[214]. After that, wisdom itself divided into its aspects is the five wisdoms, and then, entering the three times without impediment, it is the three wisdoms, and then summed up, it is the two wisdoms of knowledge of depth and extent, and then that summed up again is self-arising wisdom, the knowledge of all aspects incorporated in a single sphere. Taken from the perspective of the magnitude of the count of knowables included in space and time, that wisdom is immeasurable. Examples, count, syllogisms, and so on cannot ever come to a final assessment for wisdom, which means that his wisdom cannot be fathomed with rational mind. Therefore, it says his wisdom is unfathomable.

de lta bu'i ye shes bsam gyis mi khyab pa brnyes pa nyid kyis na/ tshig gcig gam dngos po gcig las brtsams te bskal pa dpag med du brjod kyang spobs pa gtugs pa med pas na/ spobs pa bsam gyis mi khyab pa zhes gsungs te/ mdo las/

Because the tathāgata has attained that sort of inconceivable wisdom, even if a person tried to express it by starting with one word or one thing then continued on for unfathomable kalpas, the person could still not arrive at his level of knowledgeability[215]. Thus, his knowledgeability is inconceivable. A sutra says,

'di ltar sems can kun gyis nges pa'i tshig / mang po dag gis dus gcig zhu zhus na/ / sems kyi skad cig gcig la thugs chud nas/ / gsung dbyangs gcig gis so sor lan yang 'debs/ / zhes mi 'jigs pa bzhis 'khor gyi nang du seng ge'i sgra sgrogs pa la de skad ces bya'o/ / 'di gsung gi phrin las la bshad pa snang yang gsung gi rgyu thugs kyi phrin las yin no/ /

It is like this: if all sentient beings asked Many ascertaining questions all at once, In one moment of mind it would be taken in, Then a single intonation of speech would give reply to each one, and in each one’s own language. The tathāgata proclaimed the four non-fears in the midst of his retinue with the roar of a lion[216]. Although this might seem to be an explanation of the enlightened activity of speech, the cause of speech is the enlightened activity of mind.
gnyis pa gsung
2. Speech activity
['di] la'ang tshig gnyis las/
This also is shown with two phrases.

gsung rnam par dag pa ni/ skyon dang bral ba'i cha nas te/ tshig gi cha dang don gyi cha gang nas kyang le lo sogs brgyad kyis mtshon pa'i skyon gyi tshogs rdul phra rab tsam yang med pa/ gsung de nyid kyis sngar dang rab rib chags pa nye bar sel ba smag la bla 'od ltar kun tu dga' ba 'phel ba kho na'o/ /

His speech is complete purity. This presents his speech from the aspect of its being free from faults. There is not even an atom of fault—such as illustrated by the eight faults of laziness, and so on —in his speech, either as a fault ascribed to it or a fault in fact. This speech of his with all trembling, indistinctness, and distortion totally removed, like the moon shedding light in the dark, serves only to develop total joy.

dbyangs snyan pa zhes pa/ gsung mnyen cing 'jam pa la sogs pa dbyangs kyi yan lag rgya mtsho dang ldan pas gdul bya'i rgyud la gnas skabs dga' ba dang / mthar thug phan bde'i 'bras bu stsol ba ste/ rgyud bla ma las/

His melody is pleasing. His speech with its ocean of branches of intonation[217]—smooth, gentle, and so on—now brings joy and ultimately brings the fruition of benefit and ease to the mindstreams of those to be tamed. As the Highest Continuum says,

mdor na ma lus 'jig rten khams su yang / / lta dang sa gnas bde ba'i rgyu gang yin/ / de ni ma lus 'jig rten khyab snang ba/ / dbyangs nyid la ni rab tu brten par brjod/ / ces pa la sogs pa bzhin no/ /

In short, it is the cause of every single happiness, In the worlds including the gods and the levels of their abodes. Appearing pervasively through everything of the worlds, It does, in its own intonation, express what is utterly reliable …
gsum pa sku'i phrin
3. Body activity
['di] las kyang tshig gnyis kyis bstan te/
The enlightened activity of the body is also shown with two epithets.

sku byad lta bas chog mi shes pa ni/ sku'i yan lag phra mo re re'i mdzes sdug la'ang ji tsam bltas na mig sun pa med par ma mthong ba'i dngos po gya nom pa gsar du mthong ba bzhin yid 'ong gi dga' ston rtag tu mi nyams pa ni/ sku'i byad dam bzhin lta bas ngoms pa'am chog mi shes pa zhes so/ /

One never has enough of viewing the image of his body. No matter how each minute aspect of the limbs of his body is viewed, whether it is seen as beautiful or ugly, one cannot pull one’s eyes away from his body. As with seeing something splendid that one has not seen before, the feast of delight continues on, unabated. Thus, this is saying, “Looking at his bodily form or his countenance one is not satisfied, one cannot get enough of seeing it”.

sku mtshungs pa med pa ni/ ba spu'i bu ga gcig dang 'od zer phra mo gcig gis mdzes sdug gis srid pa'i 'byo ba thams cad zis gyis gnon nus pas/ de dang mtshungs pa gzhan cung zad kyang med pa dang / gang 'dul du snang zhing / phyogs dang dus kyi tshad gzung bar mi nus pa'o/ /

His body is unparalleled. One hair pore and one subtle light ray of his body, either beautiful or ugly, will outshine anything within the riches of becoming, therefore, nothing else can parallel him, not even slightly. All together, the appearances of his body that are enacted for those to be tamed and, likewise, the measure of his body in space and time, cannot be comprehended[218].

gang gis de bzhin gshegs pa'i sku mthong ba na/ lus sems kyi sdug bsngal drag po rnams kyang rmi lam sad pa'i mtha' bzhin 'gog nus pa'i tshul rnams zhib par mdo'i gtum rgyud kyis brgyan te 'chad par bya'i/ /

Someone who sees the tathāgata’s body will have even intense suffering of body and mind cease like waking up at the end of a dream. The ways in which this happens are explained in detail in the sutras where they are embellished with stories.
gnyis pa rang don spang rtogs phun tshogs
2. The way he finalized abandonment and realization for his own sake
['di] la/ spang ba dang / rtogs pa gnyis/
The perfection of abandonment and realization for his own sake has two parts: abandonment; and realization.
dang po [spang ba]
1. Abandonment
['di] la/ srid pa'i gnas su bzhugs kyang srid pa'i skyon gyis ma gos par ston pa dang / rang gi ngo bo srid pa las 'das par ston pa gnyis/
This has two parts: showing that, even though he dwelt in the places of becoming, he remained uncontaminated by the faults of becoming; and showing how his being is beyond becoming.
dang po [srid pa'i gnas su bzhugs kyang srid pa'i skyon gyis ma gos par ston pa]
1. Showing that, even though he dwelt in the places of becoming, he remained uncontaminated by the faults of becoming

['di] la tshig gsum ste/ 'dod pa'i khams na bzhugs shing mngal nas bltams pa sogs 'jig rten mthun 'jug gi rol pa mdzad kyang / 'dod pa'i chos 'dod la 'dun pa sogs kyis cung zad kyang / ma gos pa 'dam las skyes pa'i pad+ma gzhon nu bzhin du bzhugs pa la/ 'dod pa dag gis ma gos pa zhes so/ /

This is shown with three phrases. He dwelled in the desire realm where he was born from the womb, and so on and acted out the play of doing things in accord with the world, yet in dwelling there he was not in the slightest contaminated by the dharmas of desire such as hankering after the desirables of senses, and so on. Thus— and like a fresh, young lotus sitting in a swamp—he is not contaminated by the things of desire.
de bzhen du bsam gtan mtha' dag mngon sum du mdzad kyang / de'i ro myang ba sogs kyis nye bar ram lhag par ma gos ba ste de nyid kyi phyir na/ gzugs dag gis nye bar ma gos pa zhes so/ /

Similarly, he performed all the dhyānas and gained direct experience of them yet remained very much, meaning highly, unstained because of not developing a taste or the like for them. Thus, he is very much not contaminated by the things of form.
gzugs med kyi ting 'dzin thob pa la ro myang med cing / de na chos ston pa sogs med pas der bzhugs pa'ang med phyir/ gzugs med pa dag dang ma 'dres pa zhes so/ /

He attained but did not develop a taste for the samādhis of the formless realm. He also did not teach dharma, and so on there. He also did not abide there. Therefore, he is not mixed with the things of formlessness.[219]
gnyis pa [rang gi ngo bo srid pa las 'das par ston pa]
2. Showing how his being is beyond becoming
'bras bu sdug bsngal las 'das pa dang / rgyu kun 'byung las 'das pa gnyis
This has two parts: his fruition is beyond unsatisfactoriness; and he is beyond the source, the cause of unsatisfactoriness[220].
dang po ['bras bu sdug bsngal las 'das pa] ni/
1. The fruition is beyond unsatisfactoriness
srid pa'i sa bon drung nas phyung ba'i sdug bsngal mtha' dag spangs pas na/ sdug bsngal dag las rnam par grol ba zhes mdor bstan nas/ r
He has removed the seed of unsatisfactoriness and with that abandoned the entirety of unsatisfactoriness. Thus, there is the synopsis he is completely liberated from the sufferings.

gyas bshad la/ sdug bsngal gyi gzhi phung khams skye mched las grol ba'i tshul ni/ phung po dag las rab tu rnam par grol ba zhes nye bar len pa'i phung po lnga skye zhing 'jig pa'i chos can las rab tu grol ba yin pas na de skad du'o/ /

Next is the extensive explanation, which concerns the way that he is liberated from the bases of suffering—the skandhas, dhātus, and āyatanas. The wording, he is utterly completely-liberated from the skandhas means that he is utterly liberated from the dharmins of birth and decay of the five skandhas of appropriation.[221]
khams rnams ni rang rang gi rigs kyi sa bon 'dzin pa'i don yin la/ de bzhin gshegs pa skye 'jig gi spros pa dang bral bas na khams rnams dang mi ldan pa'o/ /
The dhātus have the meaning “each one holds the seed of its own type”. Given that the tathāgata is divorced from the elaborations of birth and decay, he does not possess dhātus.[222]
skye mched rnams bsdams pa zhes/
His āyatanas are restrained.

phyi'i skye mched drug dmigs rkyen dang / nang gi drug bdag rkyen byas nas shes pa yul la 'phro zhing mchod pa la skye mched ces bya la/ de bzhin gshegs pa spros pa nye bar zhi ba'i rang bzhin gyis na/ skye mched rnams 'pho zhing g.yo ba med pas na bsdams pa zhes bya ste/ skye mched ma bsdams pa'i 'gro ba rnams ni mig gis gzugs mthong na mdzes pa la bde ba'i rnam pas chags/ mi mdzes pa la sdug bsngal gyi rnam pas sdang / bar ma la btang snyoms kyi tshor bas rmongs pa skye ba la sogs pa'o/ /

The outer six āyatanas are the referential condition and the inner six āyatanas are the governing condition. With the two, the consciousness goes out to the object and is ignited, hence the name āyatanas means “igniters”[223]. The tathāgata, due to having the quality that the elaborations have been utterly removed, does not have āyatanas that shift or move[224], thus they are called “restrained”. Migrators, whose āyatanas are not restrained, see visual forms with the eyes which produces attachment due to a pleasing aspect of beauty, aversion due to a displeasing aspect of non-beauty, or stupidity due to the neutral feeling of what lies in between, and then everything follows on from that[225].

mdor na phung po dang khams dang skye mched kyi rnam par snang yang / phung khams skye mched las 'das pa'i ye shes rnam pa thams cad pa'i sku yin pas phung sogs tha mal pa'i rang bzhin lta bu ni nam yang med do zhes so/ /

In short, the skandhas, dhātus, and āyatanas do occur for a buddha, but all of them belong to a buddha’s body which is, in every aspect, wisdom. Thus, a buddha’s skandhas, dhātus, and āyatanas are beyond those of ordinary beings, so he never has skandhas and the rest like those of ordinary beings.
gnyis pa rgyu kun 'byung spang ba
2. He is beyond the source, causes
['di] la tshig bzhi ste/
His abandonment of the source[226], causes, is stated in four phrases.
de'ang spyir nyon mongs pa'i ming du mdud pa/ yongs gdung / chu bo/ sbyor ba/ tha ba sogs rnam pa du mar gsungs pa las/ 'dir dang po gnyis byed las dang / tha ma gnyis ngo bo'i sgo nas bstan te/

In general, the Buddha taught many different names for affliction: knot, complete torment, river, enmesher, resistance, and so on. The first two epithets use some of these names to show how the afflictions function and the last two use some of them to illustrate what the afflictions actually are.

spyir nyon mongs thams cad la mdud pa zhes pa'i sgra 'jug kyang / 'dir 'khor bar 'jug pa'i rgyu'i gtso bo sred pa nyid logs su phye ba de la mdud pa zhes bya ste/ khams gsum 'khor bar 'ching ba'i byed las can mdud pa dam po dang 'dra ba de bdag med pa'i shes rab kyi ral gris bcad pa des na sred pa las rnam par grol ba yin la/ yongs su gdung ba ste sdug bsngal bar byed pa'i nyon mongs pa lta ba dang ma rig pa sogs dbang med du 'khyer ba'i shugs can chu bo lta bu'ang spangs pas na yongs su gdung ba dag las rnam par grol ba/ chu bo las brgal ba zhes so/ /

Normally, knot is a general term for affliction. Here though, it is specifically being used to refer to the primary cause of engagement in samsara, which is craving. Craving, the thing that does the work of binding beings into three-realmed samsara, is likened to a tight knot. The Buddha has cut that knot using the prajñā sword that realizes absence of self, with the result that he is completely liberated from craving. The afflictedness of views, ignorance, and so on creates suffering, so it is called all-over torment. It has the strength to carry beings off helplessly, like the current of a river. When the Buddha abandoned it, he gained complete liberation from all-over torment, therefore he has crossed over the river.[227]
de ltar na sred pas mdud pa bzhen du bsdams pa dang / nyon mongs pa'i chu bos khyer nas yongs su gdung ba ste/ rgyu 'bras phrugs bzhi po las grol lo zhes so/ /

Craving has bound beings as though they were tied with a knot and the current of afflictions’ river is carrying them away with the result that they are in complete torment. Altogether, this is saying that “he is liberated from this fourfold set of causes and effects”.
gnyis pa rtogs pa
2. Realization
['di] la/ ngo bo/ yon tan/ byed las gsum las/
Realization has three parts: entity; qualities; and function.
dang po [ngo bo]
1. Entity
['di] la rgya che ba dang / zab pa gnyis/
This has two parts: vast; and profound.
dang po [rgya che ba]
1. Vast
zag pa med pa'i chos sde tshan nyer gcig tu rnam par bzhag pa lta bu'i ye shes kyi rnam pa ma lus pa gcig kyang ma tshang ba med pa la/ ye shes yongs su rdzogs pa zhes bya'o/ /

The Buddha has every single type of wisdom—for example those presented in the twenty-one sets of un-outflowed dharmas[228]—and has them without even one missing; the epithet his wisdom is totally complete refers to this.
gnyis pa [zab pa]/
2. Profound

dus gsum du gshegs pa'i sangs rgyas thams cad dang dgongs pa mi gnyis shing so so ma yin tha mi dad pa'i dbyings dang ye shes dbyer med pa mnyam pa nyid rang byung gi ye shes la gnas pa ni/ 'das pa dang / ma byon pa dang / da ltar byung ba'i sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi ye shes la gnas pa zhes so/ /

He abides in the equality of the self-arising wisdom of expanse and wisdom inseparable. This wisdom of his is not unique to him, meaning that it is not different from, not other than, the mind of all those who go to buddhahood in the three times. Thus he abides in the wisdom of the buddha bhagavats who arise in the past, present, and future.
[yon tan]
1. Qualities

ye shes de'i yon tan ni/ srid zhi mnyam nyid du rtogs shing snying rje chen po dang ngo bo nyid kyis 'du 'bral med pas zhi ba phyogs gcig pa'i mtha' la mi gnas pas na mi gnas pa'i myang 'das zhes bya ste/ des na mya ngan las 'das pa la mi gnas pa zhes so/ / de ltar zhi ba'i dbyings phyogs gcig pa la mi gnas par phyogs dus kyis bsdus pa 'jig rten gyi khams kun na rtag tu gnas shing phan bde'i rgyur gyur na'ang / rang gi ngo bo dus gsum mnyam pa nyid chos kyi dbyings sam yang dag pa'i mtha' las g.yo ba cung zad kyang med pas na/ yang dag ba'i mtha' la gnas pa zhes so/ /

The qualities of that wisdom are as follows. He does not abide in the extreme of a one-sided peace because he has realized the equality of becoming and peace and because he has great compassion free from meeting and parting[229]. That is called “a non-abiding nirvana”. Thus, he does not abide in nirvana. Rather than abiding in a one-sided expanse of peace like that, he abides perpetually in all world systems encompassed by space and time where he is the cause of benefit and ease. At the same time, his being does not waver in the slightest from the expanse of dharmas of equality in the three times or, one could say, the limit of the authentic, therefore he abides in the limit of the authentic itself[230].
[byed las]
2. Function

byed las ni/ de ltar srid zhi'i mthar mi gnas pa'i srid zhi mnyam pa nyid kyi ye shes de nyid nges pa don gyi sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyi ye shes kyi sku'am rdo rje'i sku yin la/ de nyid la ldog chas phye ba'i sku gnyis sam gsum dang bzhi la sogs pas dbye bas/ 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i dkyil 'khor kun tu phan bde mi zad pa'i rgyur gzhom gzhig dang bral bar bzhugs pa ni rtag pa dang khyab pa dang lhun gyis grub pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa'i tshul te/ 'gro ba phal pa rnams nas rgyun mtha'i sems dpa' chen po rnams kyi bar gyi sems can thams cad la gzigs pa'i sa la bzhugs pa ste zhes so/ /

Wisdom ascertained like that to be an equality of becoming and peace that does not abide in the extremes of becoming and peace is the actual buddha bhagavat’s wisdom body or vajra kāya. It can be divided up into two or three or four, etcetera, kāyas or bodies according to specific aspects that can be distinguished in it and it is as those that he dwells imperishable, as the cause of unending benefit and bliss in all spheres both worldly and beyond worldly. The mode of this permanent and pervasive and spontaneous tathāgata is that he abides on the level of looking upon all sentient beings. Thus he abides at a level on which he is looking at all sentient beings starting from the ordinary migrators and going all the way up to the mahāsatvas at the end of the line[231].
tshig lnga po 'di dag gis chos dbyings me long mnyam nyid sor rtog bya grub kyi ye shes lnga'ang mtshon no/ /
These last five phrases also exemplify the five wisdoms of dharmadhātu, mirror, equality, individually discriminating, and all-accomplishing wisdom.
gsum pa mjug bsdu/
3. Conclusion to those sections

ji skad bshad pa 'di dag ni sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das rnams kyi sku che ba'i yon tan zhes bya ste/ sku dang lus zhes pa'ang tshogs pa sogs la 'jug pas/ 'di skabs sangs rgyas nyid la 'jug gi gsang gsum gyi zlas phye ba'i sku kho na la mi bzung ngo / /

These things that have been explained so far are the true qualities of the greatness of the body of the buddha bhagavats[232]. Here, body or kāya has the meanings “assemblage” and so on[233]. In this case, it is used to mean buddhahood itself, so it would not be good to take it to mean simply the body alone, one the three secrets[234].
yang dag pa ni sgro skur dang bral ba'i yin lugs de lta bu dag go zhes so/ /
True here means “really like this, free from overand understatement”.

de lta bu'i sangs rgyas bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i ye shes kyi sku can de ni kun rdzob tha snyad pa'i tshad mas gzhal na phyogs dus thams cad na rtug brtan gzhom gzhig dang bral ba'i rdo rje'i rang bzhin/ lhun grub phan dang bde ba mi zad pa'i gter yin la/ don dam pa'i tshad mas gzhal na rtag dang mi rtag la sogs pa'i spros pa kun las 'das pa nyid de/ yang dag par na spros pa las 'das pa de nyid kyi phyir na/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsang ba rtag khyab lhun grub bsam mi khyab pa 'di dngos stobs kyi rigs pas grub pa yin gyi/ gzhun du na de sid pa'i phyir/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i yon tan tshad med pa la dngos stobs kyi rigs pa'i lam nas yid ches par 'dod pas/

If we assess that sort of buddha of inconceivable wisdom-kāya using a fictional, conventional valid cognizer, we understand that its vajra nature of being permanent, definite, imperishable, and indestructible that spreads through all of time and space manifests in spontaneous existence which is a mine of unending benefit and ease[235]. And, if we assess it using a superfactual valid cognizer, because doing so goes beyond all elaborations of permanence, impermanence, and so on, we get to it in the authentic, where it itself is beyond elaboration. By doing all of that, we establish through the Reasoning of the Force of the Thing this inconceivable secret of the tathāgata, which is permanent, pervasive, and manifesting in spontaneous existence; if not, then it could not be what it purports to be. So, through application of logic in the form of Reasoning of the Force of Thing, we become people who decide to trust in the tathāgata’s immeasurable qualities.[236]

dpal ldan nA gA rdzu na'i dbu ma'i bstan bcos rtsa ba nas ji skad bshad pa ltar/ shes bya 'di kun rang bzhin med par nges na/ dus tshad med dang phyogs tshad med kyang rang gi ngo bos ma grub pa'i phyir rdul dang skad cig ma'i khyon du mi shong ba cung zad kyang med la/ phyogs dus kyi snang ba thams cad dus med mnyam pa nyid du mngon par mdzad pa de ni mtha' bzhi las grol ba'i ye shes kyi lus can sangs rgyas kun dang dbyer med pa chen po yin par shes nas nges pa don gyi skyabs su 'gro ba dang / de'i byin rlabs rang snang las sangs rgyas sku gsum gyi phrin las nam yang rgyun chad pa med pa'i yon tan la'ang mi phyed pa'i dad pa thob pa kho na yin pas de ltar nges par bya ste/ dbu ma rtsa ba las/

The way this is explained in Glorious Nāgārjuna’s Root Middle Way Treatise is that, if all these knowables have been ascertained to be without nature, then, even though they spread throughout immeasurable time and immeasurable regions, because they do not exist by way of self-entity, they could not, in the slightest, not be fitted into the confines of a single atom or moment. When you comprehend that the manifesting of all these appearances in space and time within timeless sameness[237] is the great point of inseparability amongst all the ones who have the wisdom body liberated from the four extremes[238], the buddhas, you will then obtain the specific certainty of the actual taking of refuge and, with it, an unfaltering faith in the good qualities of the never interrupted enlightened activity of the three buddha kāyas that arise as the selfappearances of the wisdom body’s blessings. In that way, you produce certainty; the Root Prajñā says,

gang dag sangs rgyas spros 'das shing / / zad pa med la spros byed pa/ / spros pas nyams pa de kun gyis/ / de bzhin gshegs pa mi mthong ngo / / de bzhin gshegs pa'i rang bzhin gang / / de ni 'gro 'di'i rang bzhin yin/ / zhes gsungs pa la sogs pa'i tshul du shes na de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos kyi sku rjes su dran pa ste/ rjes su dran pa thams cad kyi rgyal po yin no/ /

An elaborator in the ones who are buddha And who are beyond elaboration and unending Elaborates, causing corruption, None of which sees the tathāgata.[239] That which is the tathāgata’s nature Is these migrators’ nature … When you gain an understanding which accords with that and other statements like it, that is the recollection of the tathāgata’s dharmakāya, the king of all recollections[240].

de ltar sangs rgyas yid la byas nas gsol 'debs gcig tsam dang / phyag gcig 'tshal ba dang / me tog gcig phul ba dang / g.yeng ba'i yid kyis mtshan lan gcig brjod pa dang / 'khrugs bzhin du rtsig ngos la bris pa'i sku gzugs mthong ba tshun chad kyang dge rtsa chud mi za ba yin te/ dmigs yul sangs rgyas nyid dus gsum mnyam pa nyid kyi ye shes mthar son pa'i dbang gis bslab med cing 'da' ba med par nges te/ 'gugs byed kyi rig sngags rnon pos dang / sprul gom pa bdun pas zin pa dang / lcags kyus zin pa'i nya rnams rang gi stobs kyis rtsol mi dgos par dbang med du byed pa'i dbang gis 'jug pa bzhin no/ /

Roots of virtue created in relation to such a buddha, starting with even the smallest things such as turning the mind toward such a buddha and making just one supplication, making one prostration, or offering one flower, or distractedly expressing his name one time, or seeing while irritated a drawing of his body on the face of a wall, are never lost. The reason is that the object in these cases is a buddha who, because of having perfected the wisdom of equality of the three times, is certain to be non-deceptive and unfailing. Therefore it does happen—just like beings who have been caught by potent hooking vidyāmantras or by a seven-headed snake and just like fish who have been caught on a hook do not need to add their own efforts in order to make the outcome happen because what is going to happen is being imposed outside of their control.
'di dag kyang ma'i la du'i tshig ltar ma yin te/ rgyu dang 'bras bu'i chos nyid bsla ba med pa la rigs pas nges pa 'drongs pa dag la nges pa'i shes pa the tshom gyi smag dang bral ba skye'o/ /

The words here are not like “mother’s sweet foods”. Application of reasoning to the reality of cause and effect will give rise to certainties of mind—free of a shadow of doubt—in relation to the certainties that there are to be discovered.[241]

de ltar na phan yon tshad med pa'i de bzhin gshegs pa nyin mtshan nam rung rung du yid la bya ste/ / de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan gyi yid ge rna bar grags pa dang / de la mos pa shin tu rnyed dka' ba yin te sangs rgyas kyi mtshan ni tshad med pa'i bsod nams mi zad pa'i 'byung gnas chos nyid dang rten 'brel dang smon lam dang tingange 'dzin dang dge ba bsam gyis mi khyab pa'i mthu las sangs rgyas kyi mtshan gyi 'du byed srid pa na phan bde'i gzhir grags shing gsal ba yin te/ tshe 'di'i 'dod pa 'jo ba'i nor bu dang dpag bsam gyi shing dang bum pa bzang po bdud rtsi'i btung ba la sogs pa dag mdun du rnyed par dka' na 'di lta ci smos/ nor bu sogs kyis ni thar lam gsal bar mi nus la/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i mtshan gyis ni nam zhig byang chub tu nges par 'khrid pa'i phyir ro/ /

Thus the tathāgata of limitless benefits should always be turned to, day and night. It is extremely hard for the sound of the letters of the tathāgata’s name to come to ear causing devotion to him. The reason for that is that a buddha’s name, a source of inexhaustible, limitless merit, comes from the power of the dharmatā, interdependency, prayers of aspiration, samādhi, and inconceivable virtue, as the compounded phenomenon of a buddha’s name which becomes known and evident within becoming as a basis for the development of benefit and ease. If a jewel that produces the wishes of this life, a wish-fulfilling tree, drinking the nectar of an excellent vase, and so on are hard to actually have in front of you, what could be said of this? Jewels, and so on cannot elucidate the path of emancipation whereas the tathāgata’s name will definitely lead, at some point in time, to enlightenment.

de la de bzhin gshegs pa'i gsang ba bsam mi khyab pa'i byin rlabs las snang ba'i mtshan gyis phun sum tshogs pa'i bde ba ster bar byed pa'ang dngos po'i chos nyid rten 'brel gyi nus pa bsam mi khyab pa nam yang bslu ba med pa yin te/ legs par brtags na nor bu sogs bem po rdul du ma tshogs pa dang / grub pa'i rigs sngags dag kyang ngag gi sgra skad cig du ma'i phreng ba las bden par grub pa cung zad med kyang / bsten pa po la phun sum tshogs pa'i dpal ster ba la bsnyon du med pa bzhin rang bzhin stong pa nyid kyi dbang gis dngos po'i nus pa rten 'byung bslu ba med pa la yid ches par byas na sgrub pa thams cad don dang ldan pa nyid do/ /

In regard to that, the name which appears from the blessings of the tathāgata’s inconceivable secret is not only the dispenser of perfect ease but belongs to the reality of things with its inconceivable capabilities of interdependency that are always non-deceptive. For that reason, if this is carefully examined, we find that jewels, and so on are assemblages of many physical atoms and vidyāmantras of accomplishment are strings of many moments of sound of speech and, therefore, not one of them has the slightest true existence. Nevertheless, it is undeniable that they give the one who uses them great glories[242], and similarly, if, because of the nature of emptiness, you have trust in the capability of things which is their non-deceptive interdependency, then everything you do will be meaningful.

mdo las kyang / sems can rnams la nyin re bzhin/ / bskal pa gang+gA'i bye ma snyed / lha yi zas gos byin pa bas/ / dge bsnyen gcig la zan gcig byin/ / de bas bsod nams grangs med bskyed/ / dge slong dad pa'i rjes 'brang dang / / rgyun zhugs phyir 'ong phyir mi 'ong / / dgra bcom rang rgyal bar du sbyar/ / la las phyogs bcu'i rdul snyed kyi/ / rang rgyal rnams la nyin re bzhen/ / bskal pa gang+gA'i bye ma snyed/ / lha yi zas gos byin pa'am// gang gis sangs rgyas sgra thos sam/ / sangs rgyas sku gzugs bris pa'am/ / 'jim pa las byas mthong pa yang / / de bas bsod nams ches lhag na/ / sku mthong thal mo sbyar ba'am// bsngags pa tshig gcig tsam brjod dam/ / mchod pa byed pa lta ci smros/ / gang gis sangs rgyas mtshan bzung ste/ / yid ches mos shing mi spong na/ / zhing bcu rin po che yis bkang // sangs rgyas rnams la nyin re bzhin/ / bskal pa gang+gA'i bye snyed du/ / phul ba'i dge bas dper mi phod/ / gzhan yang mtshan tsam bzung ba la'ang / / tshe 'di nyid dang phyi mar yang // phan yon mtha' yas gsung gyur na/ / rgyal ba'i bsngags pa 'di lta bu/ / klog dang yid byed sgros ci dgos/ / zhes gsungs pas mtshon te rgyas par mdo rnams las shes par bya'o//

Also, it says in a sutra, Compared to offering To sentient beings daily For as many kalpas as sands in the Ganges, Food and clothes of the gods, Offering one buddhist layman one meal Generates a countless amount of merit. A full monk who follows with faith, Stream-enterers who will return and not, Up to a pratyeka arhat are then joined to this[243]. Some offer to pratyekas as many as atoms In the ten directions, daily, For as many kalpas as sands of the Ganges, Food and clothes of the gods. Compared to that, one who hears the sound buddha or Sees a drawing of buddha’s form body or One made from clay, Has more merit, so what need to mention Seeing the body, joining the palms, Expressing even one word of praise, or Making an offering? For someone who apprehends the name buddha, When there is trust, devotion, and no rejection, The virtue of offering the ten fields filled With precious things to the buddhas daily For as many kalpas as the sands of the Ganges Cannot compare. Furthermore, for apprehending just the name Infinite advantages also were foretold For this life and later ones as well, So what need to mention reading and directing the mind To this kind of praise of the conqueror … That gives an idea of it and it can then be known more extensively from the sutras.
gnyis pa chos rjes su dran pa
2. Recollection of the dharma
['di] la/ mdor bstan dang / rgyas bshad gnyis/
This has two parts: a synopsis; and an extensive explanation.
dang po [mdor bstan]/
1. Synopsis
dam pa'i chos ni zhes pa nas yongs su byang ba zhes pa'i bar gyis bstan te/
This goes from the holy dharma … up to … is thoroughly purifying.

de la spyir Du d+ha nya 'dzin pa'i byings las bsgrubs pa'i d+harmA'i sgra ni shes bya dang lam sogs bcu la 'jug ste/ chos shes bya rang gi mtshan nyid 'dzin pa dang / dge bcu sogs ngan song las 'dzin pa dang / lam mtha' gnyis las 'dzin pa yin pa sogs kyis skabs so sor go ba len dgos kyang / 'di skabs dam pa'i chos zhes shes bya'i chos rnams kyi nang na dam pa dang / rab dang / phul du gyur pa ni rgyu lam dang / 'bras bu 'gog pa myang 'das kyi chos gnyis dang / de'i rgyu mthun lung gi chos dang bcas pa ste/

Generally, the term dharma, which is produced from the root “ḍudha” meaning “holder of a fish”[244], has the ten usages of “knowable”, and the rest[245]. For each usage, a specific connotation of “holding” is understood: a dharma which is a knowable is so because it holds its own characteristic; dharma which is the ten virtues, and so on is so because it holds one back from the bad migrations; dharma which is the path is so because it holds one back from the two extremes; and so on. The wording here in the text is holy dharma which is understood like this: within dharmas that are knowables, the holy or best or outstanding ones are the two dharmas of causal path and fruition—which is cessation, nirvana and, together with the two, that which corresponds to their cause, the dharma of authoritative statement.
mdor na lung dang rtogs pa'i dam pa'i chos zhes bya'o/ /
In short, the holy dharma is “the holy dharma of authoritative statement and realization”[246].

de lta bu'i dam chos de ni/ thog mar thos pa'i dus su yid ches kyi dad pa skye bas thog mar dge ba dang / bar du bsam byung gi shes pas don myong na gtan bde'i lam gyi nges pas dga' ba khyad par can skye bas bar du dge ba'am legs pa dang / mthar bsgom pa'i dus su yang dag pa'i ye shes 'byung bas srid pa gtan du ldog pas na tha mar dge ba ste gsum yin la yang na rim pa ltar brjod bya bslab pa gsum ste/ tshul khrims dang / ting 'dzin/ shes rab gsum ston pas na lam gyi rim pa dang mthun par thog ma bar dang tha mar dge ba zhes bshad de/ skabs de dang de na gtso che ba'i nyams len gyi rim pas so/ /

The holy dharma like that is good in the beginning because, at the beginning, when you hear it, trusting faith is born. It is good or fine in the middle because, in the middle, you taste the meaning through thinking about it and then, having become certain that it is a path of definite happiness, a special joy is born in you. And it is good at the end because, at the end when you meditate on it, authentic wisdom arises causing your definite reversal from existence. It is those three, as stated. Alternatively, this could be done in relation to what is being expressed there—the three principal trainings, taught as śhīla, samādhi, and prajñā. Done that way, “good in the beginning, middle, and end” is explained in relation to those three, a presentation which accords with the stages of the path, and the principal stages of practice in particular.

don bzang po ni/ kun rdzob dang don dam pa'i bden pa rnam pa gnyis kyi mtshan nyid phyin ci ma log par ston pa yin pas/ don med ba bya rog so brtag gi bstan bcos lta bu dang / don chung ba shing gi lo ma'i grangs dang lus kyi srin bu'i grangs ston pa lta bu'i nyi tshe ba ma yin par shes bya mtha' dag gi yul la rmongs pa bzlog nus ba'i don gtan la 'bebs pas so/ /

Its meaning is excellent. The holy dharma unmistakenly teaches the characteristics of the two truths, fictional and superfactual. Thus, it does not deal with subjects of passing benefit, either those of no meaning such as found in treatises that examine a crow’s beak[247] or those of lesser meaning such as ones that consider the count of leaves on trees or the count of micro-organisms in the body. Rather, it gets to the meaning that has the capacity to reverse stupidity in regard to the entire domain of what can be known.

tshig 'bru bzang po ni/ ming tshig yi ge'i 'du byed yul de la ma grags pa dang sdeb sbyor dkrugs pa sogs dang / brjod tshul mi legs pa'i skyon med pa ste/ phyi rol pa'i bstan bcos kha cig ltar/ ched du ngag 'khyogs pos go dka' bar byas pa lta bu min par/ de bzhin gshegs pa'i snying rje'i thugs kyis gdul bya'i blo dang 'tshams par go bde zhing mdzin sla la don gsal zhing rna bar snyan pa'o/ /

Its wording is excellent. In terms of the words produced from letters, there are none of the faults of nonsensical wording, mixedup composition, and so on, nor of less-than-good expression in the composition built up from the words. Unlike what is found in the treatises of the outsiders, where various factions use incomprehensible wordings to express their dharma, the tathāgata’s mind of compassion used wording that fitted the minds of those to be tamed. Therefore, his wordings are easy to understand, easy to memorize, clear in meaning, and pleasant to hear[248].

ngo bo'i cha nas tshangs spyod kyi yon tan bzhi dang ldan pa ste/ de'ang ma 'dres pa ni/ gzhan mu stegs sogs dang thun mong min pa'i phra ba'i mi rtag pa dang 'du byed kyi sdug bsngal dang / bdag med pa sogs ston pa des na gzhan dang ma 'dres ba thun min gyi yon tan te/

From the perspective of the thing itself[249], the holy dharma possesses the four qualities of brahmacharya[250]. As a result it is not adulterated. This dharma which teaches subtle and uncommon impermanence, formatives’ suffering[251], lack of self, and so on is not mixed in with the dharmas of others, the Tīrthikas[252] and the rest, and does have an uncommon quality to it.

ji skad du/ nyon mongs dgra rnams ma lus 'chos pa dang / / ngan 'gro'i srid las skyob pa gang yin pa/ / 'chos skyob yon tan phyir na bstan bcos te/ / gnyis po 'di dag gzhan gyi lugs la med/ / ces pa lta bu'o/ /

That has been said like this, One that corrects every one of the enemies of the afflictions and Protects from the bad migrations of becoming, Because it has the qualities of correcting and protecting, is a treatise; These two are not present in the systems of others.[253]

yongs su rdzogs pa ni/ 'dod pa lta bu'i nyon mongs pa phyogs re dang / nad kyi gnyen po sman lta bu sdug bsngal phyogs re zhi ba'i thabs nyi tshe ba ma yin par khams gsum gyi nyon mongs pa mtha' dag drung nas 'byin pa'i gnyen po yongs su rdzogs pa ste/

It is totally complete. It is not like methods that take a short-term approach and so only partially alleviate suffering. It is not like medicine for a specific disease that cures only that much of the problem, for example, it is not a cure for only one of the afflictions, such as desire. Instead, it is a totally complete antidote that removes the afflictions of the three realms in their entirety.

rgyal tshab dam pas/ gang zhig don ldan chos dang nyer 'brel zhing / / khams gsum kun nas nyon mongs spong byed gsung / / zhi ba'i phan yon ston par mdzad ba gang / de ni dang srong gsung yin ldog pa gzhan/ / zhes gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

It is similar to what the holy regent said, He said, “What is meaningful is to stay closely involved with the dharma; Doing so abandons the afflictions from all three realms”. What functions to show the advantages of peace Is the ṛiṣhis’ speech, just another conceptualized thing[254].

yongs su dag pa zhes pa shes bya chos dbyings rang bzhin rnam dag gi ngo bo la dri ma ye nas dag pa nyid brjod byar ston pa yin la/ de la dmigs pa'i yul can gyi ye shes kyang chos kyi dbyings dang rjes su mthun pas phyin ci log gi sbros pas dben pa yin par bstan pa'o/ /

It is total purity. The nature of the expanse of knowable dharmas is complete purity, a purity of being primordially free of stains. The holy dharma is taught in order to express that purity. It is taught by wisdom that views that purity which is apart from the corruptions of elaboration[255] because it is in harmony with the expanse of dharmas.

yongs su byang ba zhes pa chos dbyings ngo bo nyid kyis dag pa la/ de ltar ma rtogs pa'i glo bur gyi dri ma'i cha bag chags dang bcas pa rnams kyang gshis ma nor bar 'jal ba'i lam gyis sbyangs te gnas lugs ji bzhin pa mngon du byed pa'i glo bur bral dag gi cha nas de skad du gsungs pa'o/ /

It is total purification. The dharmadhātu or expanse of dharmas is pure of being a thing in itself. However, the mind possessing adventitious stains together with their latencies does not realize it that way. The path that leads to unmistaken cognition of the innate disposition[256] purifies the adventitious stains until they are purified. Thus, this statement about the holy dharma concerns its making actuality just as it is manifest, divorced from adventitious stains, through this process of purification[257].
de ltar tshangs pa zhes pa myang 'das yin la/ de'i lam mam spyod pa yin pa'i chos ni tshangs spyod kyi yon tan bzhi dang ldan pa zhes so/ /

That sort of thing referred to as “Brahmā”, meaning “the Pure One”, is nirvana. The dharma which is its path or “charya” meaning “way of behaviour” is then said to possess the four qualities of “brahmacharya” or “ways of purity”.

de ltar dge ba gsum dang / bzang po gnyis dang / tshangs spyod bzhi bo 'di dag mdo sde rgyan las kyang / dad dang dga' dang blo rnams kyi/ / rgyu phyir chos 'di dge ba yin/ / don rnam gnyis ldan gzung sla dang / / yon tan bzhi can tshang spyod ston/ / ces

Those three goodnesses, two excellences, and four types of conduct of brahma or purity are mentioned in the Ornament of the Sutra Section[258], too. They are similar to what it says there: This repairing which is the cause of those of Faith and joy and intelligence is virtue. Having the two types of meaning, it is easy to comprehend, and Having the four qualities shows conduct of the pure.[259]

dang / tshangs spyod bzhi yang / gzhan dang thun ming ma yin ldan pa dang / / khams gsum nyon mongs rnams spong rdzogs byed dang / / ngo bo nyid dag dri mas dag pa ste/ / tshangs spyod yon tan bzhi ldan yin par 'dod/ / ces gsungs pa bzhin no/ /

and, The four ways of purity— Others and having the uncommon, Completely performs abandonment of the afflictions, The essence pure, and the stains purified— Are asserted to hold the four qualities of conduct of the pure, brahmacharya.[260]
gnyis pa rgyas bshad
2. Extensive explanation
['di] la/ blang bya'i mchog tu bstan pa dang / gtan gyi yid brtan du bstan pa'o/ /
This has two parts: showing that it is the supreme one to be accepted; and showing that it is a definite mental reliance.
dang po [blang bya'i mchog tu bstan pa]
1. Showing that it is the supreme one to be accepted
['di] la mdor bstan/ rgyas bshad gnyis/
This has two parts: a synopsis; and an extensive explanation.
dang po [mdor bstan]/
1. Synopsis
bcom ldan 'das kyis chos legs par gsungs pa zhes/
The bhagavat has taught dharma well.

shes bya mtha' dag la ye shes kyi gzigs pa sgrib med du 'jug pa tshad ma'i skyes bu sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis bstan pa'i chos ni skyon kun bral yon tan kun rdzogs kyi bdag nyid legs par gsungs pa kho na yin no/ / zhes gzhan rmongs pas bslad pa phyi rol ba'i lugs la 'gal pa'i gnod pa du ma'i nyes pa dang bcas pas na legs par bshad pa med do/ / ces so/ /

The dharma teaching taught by the buddha bhagavat, a being of valid cognition, whose wisdom looks at the entirety of knowables, seeing them without obscuration, is a body of teaching free from all faults and complete in all qualities that is only good teaching. What this really says is, “The other teachers are tainted with absence of knowledge and their outsider systems contain harmful things contrary to dharma together with many faults. Therefore, theirs are not good explanations”.
gnyis pa rgyas bshad
2. Extensive explanation
['di] la/ skyon bral ba'i cha nas dang / yon tan ldan pa'i cha nas bstun pa gnyis/
This has two parts: shown from the perspective of being free of faults; and shown from the perspective of having good qualities.
dang po [skyon bral ba'i cha nas]/
1. Shown from the perspective of being free of faults
yang dag par mthong sogs tshig gsum gyi don/
The meaning of the three phrases here, it is authentic sight, and so on are as follows.

ji ltar legs par gsungs pa yin na/ yang dag par mthong ba'am/ dpe la lar yang dag par bstan pa zhes gsungs te/ dngos po'i gnas tshul ma nor bar mig gsal bas gzugs la bltas pa bzhin du gzigs nas/ don de bzhin du bstan pa yin pas/ gdul bya rnams kyis kyang 'di la brten nas gnas lugs ma nor bar mthong nus pas na yang dag par mthong ba ste/ 'di la 'khrul pa med ces pa'i tha tshig

The dharma taught by the Buddha was well-taught dharma. In what ways did he teach the dharma well? Firstly, it is authentic sight or, as some editions say, “it is the authentic shown”[261]. The Buddha views the actuality of phenomena unmistakenly, like an eye that is actually seeing the visual forms it is looking at. He then teaches in accordance with fact, with the result that those to be tamed who use his teaching also are able to see actuality unmistakenly. Thus, the Buddha’s dharma is authentic sight, which has to be understood in the final analysis to mean “is without confusion”.

go dka' chen gyi 'grel pa na tshig tsam min par don la dpyad nas nges pa thob dgos pa'i don du 'chad kyang / 'di chos kyi yon tan dran pa'i ldog char ma song bar gang zag gi nyams len gyi tshig gcig bar du ston pa mi 'brel lo/ /

There are some very complicated commentaries which explain that the meaning of this epithet requires ascertainment not just through the simple use of words but through analysis of reality. However, that sort of thing does not become an aspect of recollecting the good qualities and is not connected with teaching even one word of practice for a person[262].

nad med pa zhes pa/ nad ni nyon mongs pa'i rnam grangs yin la/ nyon mongs pa bag la nyal bcas drung nas 'byin pa'i zag med kyi chos 'di'i ngo bo ni nyi ma'i dkyil 'khor la mun pa'i skabs mi thob pa bzhin du zag pa'am nad nyon mongs pa med pa'o/ / des na 'jig rten pa'i sgyu rtsal la sogs pa'i bstan bcos dang / rigs pa thams cad zag pa nyon mongs dang mi 'gal par mtshungs ldan du 'jug pa yin la 'di ni de las khyad par du 'phags pa'o/ /

It is free from sickness. Sickness is a word for affliction. This unoutflowed dharma that removes afflictions together with their latencies is, in itself, free from outflow or sickness, the afflictions. It is like the sun’s disk which, in itself, never goes dark. On the other hand, there are all kinds of treatises on worldly arts and crafts, and so on, but these are not the opposites of outflows or afflictions and so end up being equivalent to them. This dharma is superior to all of that[263].

dus chad pa med pa zhes pa ni/ 'di skyon bral yon tan ldan pa yin du zin kyang / 'di la yid brtan du byas na'ang nam zhig 'di'i yon tan gyis mi skyob pa'i dus shig yod dam snyam na de med de/ 'di ltar nor bu dang bum bzang sogs phan pa'i dngos po bzang po yang dus chad pa med par phan 'dogs pa min na'ang / 'dis ni spang bya spangs pa slar mi ldog cing / 'phags lam gyis thob pa'i rtogs rigs las kyang yongs su nyams pa med pas na/ 'di ni dus rgyun chad pa'am zad pa med pa zhes bya'o/ /

Its time has no interruption. You might think, “Granted that this is free from fault and has good qualities, but if it were taken as a point of mental reliance, would there be a time at which its qualities did not provide refuge?” The answer is no, there is not. Good things that are beneficial in being able to provide some protection, such as jewels, excellent vases, and so on are not beneficial continuously. However, when what has to be abandoned has been abandoned through the use of this holy dharma, there is no return to that again; because of that, the type of realization that is attained to by means of the noble path does not degenerate. Thus, this holy dharma is said to be “uninterrupted in its time” or “unending in its time”.
de dag kyang dngos stobs kyi rigs pas bsgrubs pa'i yid ches par bya ste 'dir yi ge mangs kyis dogs nas ma bris so/ /
These should also be proven trustworthy using the Reasoning of the Force of the Thing but I have not written about it here out of concern that would need to be a lengthy discussion.
gnyis pa yon tan ldan pa'i cha nas rjes su dran tshul
2. Shown from the perspective of having good qualities
['di] la tshig gsum ste/
This has three phrases associated with it.

de yang / nye bar gtod pa zhes pa sdug kun gyis bsdus pa'i spang bya mtha' dag spangs pa'i zag med kyi bde ba gtan du ba 'dis rang rgyud la gtod par byed pa ste/ rgyu 'di las gzhan du shes bya'i khongs na rnam grol gyi bde ba nye bar gtod nus pa med do zhes so/ /

It brings one in. This holy dharma, the definite state of un-outflowed bliss attained through the abandonment of the entirety of what is to be abandoned—all miserable things—serves to bring one’s own mindstream in to itself. In other words, this phrase is saying, “Except for this cause, nothing else in the entire vault of knowables has the capability to bring you into the bliss of complete liberation”.
ji ltar gtod na 'di la thos bsam sgom pas zhugs pa de/ rim gyis srid pa'i gnas nas drangs te zag med kyi dbyings su 'dren par byed pas so/ /

How does it bring one in? It gradually leads a person who has entered the dharma through hearing, contemplating, and meditating in from the places of becoming then guides him into the unoutflowed expanse[264].
de'ang rgya dper u pan yi ka zhes nye bar gtod pa'am/ nye bar 'dren pa zhes 'byung ngo zhes gsungs so/ /

This epithet in Indian texts is the phrase “upanāyika”. It has been translated into Tibetan with “nye bar gtod pa ‹› brings in close”. It has also been translated with “nye bar ’dren pa ‹› leads in close”, which is the meaning exactly of the original words.[265]

'di mthong ba la don yod pa zhes pa thog ma med pa nas 'khor ba sdug bsngal gyi rgya mtsho chen po na 'khyams pa rnams/ da rung du yang dam pa'i chos dang ma 'phrad nyams su ma blangs na mtha' thug pa med par sdug bsngal bzod dka' ba'i 'dam du dbang med du 'phyan par 'dug pa la/ 'di dang 'phrad na rgya mtsho'i dbus su gru dang 'phrad pa ltar mkhas pa rnams 'di la brten nas sdug bsngal gyi chu gter chen po'i pha rol tu slar mi ldog par 'gro ba yin pas shes bya'i khongs na mthong ba'am shes pa la 'di las don che ba gzhan med cing / don gyi mchog mthar thug pa 'di la yod pas de skad ces bya'o/ /

This is meaningful to see. Those who have been wandering in samsara, a great ocean of suffering, from beginningless time will continue to flounder about helplessly in the mire of difficult-tobear suffering until they meet the holy dharma and practise it. When wise ones meet the dharma, it will be like meeting with a boat in the middle of the ocean, and they will rely on it and go, without the possibility of return, to the far shore of the great waters that are a reservoir of suffering. By doing so, they come to “see”, where see means to know, the whole vault of knowables. There is nothing of greater meaning than that, and in addition, the holy dharma has in it the ultimate, supreme meaning, so it is spoken of with this phrase.

de la 'khor ba 'di sdug bsngal gyi rang bzhin dang / de'i gzhen po chos kho nar shes shing / de la brten nas 'khor ba'i sdug bsngal bsrab par byas pas yid ches kyi mig can dag gis ni kye ma'o gsung 'di ni ches bden pa nyid do zhes shin tu nges par 'gyur te/ gzhan rmongs pa gang dag dam chos lag tu mchis pa'ang sdong bar byed pa rnams la tshig tsam du snang gi don mi myong ngo / /

Those who understand what this is saying—that the nature of this samsara is suffering and that its only antidote is the dharma—and who then rely on the dharma to eradicate their samsaric sufferings will develop an eye of trust that is very certain about the dharma. They will say, “Oh my goodness! This speech of the buddha is a great truth!” Others who are stupid might have this holy dharma in their hands but, because they view it as words only and do not see it as the instrument that actually does the work of abandoning samsara, they never actually experience its meaning.
rgya dpe la lar e hi pra shrI kaH zhes 'byung ba 'dir ltos shig tu bsgyur ba'ang 'di las don chen po 'byung bas na ltos shig ces pa yin kyang gong ltar bsgyur ba legs so/ /

Indian editions of the text have a phrase that does not correspond to the Tibetan wording “ ’di mthong ba la don yod pa ‹› this is meaningful to see” of this epithet. They have the phrase “ehipaśhrīkaḥ” which translates as “ltos shig ‹› look at it!” which implies that a great meaning comes from doing so. Although the original wording is “Look at it!”, it seems better to translate it as done in the Tibetan version.

mkhas pa rnams kyis so so rang gis rig par bya ba zhes shin tu zab cing rtog ge dang 'jig rten pa'i blo phal ba'i spyod yul min par bstan pa ste/ don gyi gnas tshul gzigs pa'i mkhas pa 'phags pa rnams kyis so so rang rig pa'i ye shes kyi yul du 'di mngon sum 'gyur la/ 'on kyang rdzogs par yul du byed pa mkhas pa mthar thug pa sangs rgyas kho na'i yul lo/ / don spyi'i tshul gyis 'jal ba'ang shin tu zhib mo'i blo can mkhas pa'i sbyod yul yin ces so/ /

It is known to experts through personal self-knowing shows that the dharma is extremely profound and that it is not the domain of the ordinary rational mind of philosophers or worldly types. The experts who see the factual situation are the noble ones. They see it in direct perception as an object of personal self-knowing wisdom. Note that it is only the Buddha amongst them who is the ultimate wise one and who has fully made the factual situation into the object of the self-knowing. This phrase is saying, “It could be assessed using generic facts but that would still be the domain of those experts who have rational mind that knows in very fine detail”.[266]

de la so so rang rig pa zhes so so ni gzhan dang ma 'dres pa'i don yin la/ rang zhes pa yul de dag gi ngo bo ma nor ba dang / rig pa zhes mthong ba ste sgra bsdoms na gzhan bum sogs shes pa'i mig shes lta bu tshur mthong gis 'di mi shes kyi/ 'di rang nyid shes pa'i shes pa gcig pu ste thun mong min pa'i blo cig gi yul yin pa'o/ / des na so so rang rig pa'i ye shes dang ldan pa rnams kyi spyod yul yin pas thun mong min pa 'jig rten las 'das pa'i yon tan dag / bsgoms pa'i myong bas reg na mi 'gyur ba'i yid ches kyi gnas yin no ces pa'i don to/ / de ltar shes bya'i khongs na blang ba'am bcad par bya ba'i mchog ni dam pa'i chos yin par bstan nas/ da ni gnyis pa de la blang zhing bzung na gtan du yid brtan du rung ba'i tshul gsung ba la/

In the phrase “personal self-knowing”: personal has the meaning “not mixed in with other”; self has the meaning “the entity of those objects un-mistaken”; and knowing has the meaning “to see”. When put together it goes like this. Consciousness that works by being conscious of other—like an eye consciousness registers vases, and so on—will not know this profound dharma by looking in towards itself. Rather, this profound dharma will be known only by a knower that knows itself. This is the object only of an uncommon type of rational mind[267]. Therefore, the meaning here is, “The dharma is the domain of those who have personal self-knowing wisdom[268]. Because of that, the places where you can put your hopes and which are places of unchanging trust are the non-ordinary, beyond-the-world qualities experienced through meditation”. Thus the first part of this section has taught that the holy dharma is the excellence that could be gained or taken from within the vault of knowables. The second part presents the way that this dharma will, if taken up, be a definite reliance for mind.
[gtan gyi yid brtan du bstan pa]
2. Showing that it is a definite mental reliance
bstan bshad gnyis/
This has two parts: a synopsis; and an extensive explanation.
dang po [bstan]/
1. Synopsis

bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa'i chos 'dul ba la legs par brten pa zhes/ de la kha cig 'di snyam du sangs rgyas kyi chos ni la lar phung sogs yod par bstan/ la lar med par bstan/ la lar gnyis kar bstan/ la lar gnyis min du bstan pa sogs mtha' yas pas yid brtan du dka' snyam na/ de lta min te/ tshad ma'i skyes bu sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis gdul bya'i khams dbang bsam pa legs par mkhyen nas nor bu rin po che phyi dor byed pa bzhin du/ bden pa gnyes las brtsams pa'i chos rags pa dang phra ba dang shin tu phra ba dang mthar thug pa'i don rnams ci tsam bzod par bstan pa de thams cad gdul bya'i rgyud kyi nyon mongs gdul ba la 'gro zhing / mthar thug gi byang chub la gzhol ba sha stag yin gyi/ don so so dang 'gal ba dang / yang dag pa'i don mi ston pa tshig gcig kyang med par thams cad mthar thug gi byang chub gcig la 'gal ba med par 'jug pa yin pas na de skad ces bya ste/

The dharma spoken by the bhagavat serves well for taming[269]. In relation to this, one person had the thought, “It would be hard for the Buddha’s dharma to be a mental reliance given its infinite variety of presentation; he taught it to some as ‘the skandhas, and so on exist’, he taught to others as ‘they do not exist’, he taught it to some as both, to some as neither, and so on”. However, that is not the case. The buddha bhagavat, a being of valid cognition, knows well the elements, faculties, and thoughts of those to be tamed. Because of that, he taught each part of the dharma patiently, as one would do the work of wiping and rubbing a precious jewel. He began by teaching the two truths coarsely, then he taught them more precisely, then with great precision, and finally in their ultimate meaning[270]. Every bit of that teaching went to taming the afflictions of the mindstreams of those to be tamed and every bit of it was presented only for arriving at the meaning of ultimate enlightenment; it is not that the meanings involved contradict one another or that sometimes he did not teach the authentic meaning. Every word of the dharma without exception applies without contradiction to the one, ultimate enlightenment, therefore these words are used to describe it.

dpe la lar legs par ston pa zhes 'byung ba'ang don de 'dra'o/ / 'grel pa kha cig na yid rton gyi sgrar byas nas de'ang 'dul ba'i bcas mtshams la gces spras bgyid pa'i don du bshad pa ni skad dod dang don gyi 'brel gnyis char brtags pas gzhung gi dgongs pa yin min shes par nus so/ /

Some texts have instead of “legs par brten pa ‹› serves well” the words “legs par ston pa ‹› well taught”, though the basic meaning is the same. There is also a thread of commentary which, basing itself on the term “mental reliance”, explains these words to mean “caring for the restrictions that come with the Vinaya”[271]. This raises the need for examining the translation equivalents involved and commentaries on the meaning; doing so will let us to know what is and is not the meaning intended in the text itself.
gnyis pa rgyas bshad
2. Extensive explanation
['di] la tshigs drug las/
This consists of six phrases.
dang po gnyis ni/ nges par 'byung ba/ rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu 'gro bar byed pa/ zhes
The first two are: It is renunciation. It causes one to go to complete enlightenment.

dam pa'i chos thams cad mthar thug don dam ba'i rnam pa gcig tu gzhol ba de ji ltar yin snyam na/ kun nyon rags pa nas brtsams te ma rig bag chags kyi sa'i bar gyi spang bya ma lus pa las nges par 'byung ba'i thabs sna tshogs dang ldan pa spangs pa phun tshogs kyi rgyu byed pa'i cha nas nges par 'byung ba dang / sgrib gnyis kyi dri ma zad pa na de nyid du bla med rdzogs pa'i byang chub rtogs bya'i mthar thug pa'ang brnyes pa yin pas na rdzogs pa'i byang chub tu 'gro bar byed pa zhes gsungs te/

You might wonder, “How could renunciation possibly be able to validly see the whole of the holy dharma, and arrive at a final understanding of it as one, ultimate superfactual type?” Renunciation—when taken to mean the renunciation that consists of various methods of renunciation in light of all of the things to be abandoned starting at the coarse level of total affliction and going up to the level of ignorance latencies[272]—is the cause of a perfect abandonment. Furthermore, when the stains of the two obscurations have been exhausted, that perfect abandonment itself is the attainment of the ultimate of realizations, unsurpassed complete enlightenment. Thus it is saying that renunciation causes one to go to complete enlightenment.

spang bya mtha' dag spangs shing / rtogs bya mtha' dag rtogs pa'i byang chub chen por 'bab cing gzhol pas mthar thug theg gcig tu bstan pa yin no/ / de nyid kyi phyir na dam pa'i chos kyi bstan bya mtha' dag gcig yin na gcig spang dgos pa'i 'gal ba cung zad kyang med par thams cad 'gal med lam kyi cha rkyen gcig tu rdzogs pas/ gdul bya'i bsam pa'i dbang gis sangs rgyas kyi chos tshad med pa'ang mi mthun pa med cing / mi mthun pa med pa tsam du ma zad/ 'og ma'i yon tan gyi cha thams cad gong mar 'du zhing mi phyed pas de dag thams cad gnad gcig tu tshang ba la 'dus pa dang ldan pa zhes gsungs te/ dam pa'i chos sna tshogs pa don so so ba 'gal ba yang yin/ gcig gcig la mi 'du ba yin na mthar thug gi yid brtan du mi rung yang / de ltar ma yin pas chos che chung rang gis ji tsam bzod pa de la'ang gtan du yid brtan rung zhes pa'o/ /

Having this final understanding of great enlightenment as the abandonment of the entirety of what is to be abandoned and the realization of the entirety of what is to be realized is the teaching of a single, ultimate vehicle. Following on from that, if the entirety of what is to be taught as the holy dharma is one thing, there being not the slightest contradiction over what needs to be abandoned, then everything is complete in one, non-contradictory, conducive path. Thus, although the Buddha’s dharma might be immeasurable because of the thoughts of those to be tamed, it is without any disharmony[273]. And it is not just free of all disharmony; all of the lower level qualities are contained in the higher level ones and do not falter[274], therefore all of them are complete in one key point, and so it is also the case that it has inclusion. Now, the individual meanings of some of the holy dharmas are contradictory. Following on from that, if one were not included within the other, then the dharma could not be suitable as an ultimate mental reliance. However, that it is not so; dharma of any stature[275] can withstand anything and because of that the dharma is said to be “suitable as a definite mental reliance”.

'di lta bu'i gnad ma rtogs par nyan thos kyi chos ni dman pa'o snyam du sems pa dag ni de bzhin gshegs pa'i chos zab cing rgya che ba'i tshul yid ngor ma shong nas chos spong ba'i phung krol la zhugs pa yin no/ /

If because of not comprehending this key point you think, “The dharma of the śhrāvakas is lesser”, then the tathāgata’s dharma with its profound and vast approaches will not fit with your mind and your mind will start to entertain ideas that his dharma is meaningless and to be discarded.
brten pa yod pa/ rgyu ba bcad pa zhes/
It has reliability. It does end the journey.

spyir 'dus byas zag bcas kyi chos gang dang gang la brten pa thams cad mthar mi 'jig pa med pas 'khor los sgyur ba dang tshangs dbang sogs kyi srid thob na'ang / de la brten pa med pa yin te/ rang nyid thob pa po de la 'dun cing ma gtong na yang / thob bya'i ngos nas brten pa med pa'am gzung du mi rung bar 'gyur ba yin la/ chos ni de 'dra ma yin te/ brten po rang gis chos ma btang na chos la brtan pa'am gtad so 'cha' mi nus pa zhig phyogs dus kyi cha gang na'ang mi srid pas so/ /

Generally, all of the composite dharmas with outflows, whatever and wherever, are in the end not “imperishable”. Thus, even though you attain the sovereignty of someone such as a wheel-wielder[276], Brahmā, Indra, or the like, it will be a situation that is without reliability. You, as the one who attains it, might want it and decide that you will not let go of it but, from its side, the position attained does not have reliability and is not suited to being taken up for that purpose. Dharma is not like that because, as long as you, the one reliant on it, do not let go of it, it cannot, anywhere or anytime, lose its ability to remain reliable or to stay on course.

'di la brten pa zhes pa chos rten du bas nas de'i steng na brten pa pos brten pa de nam yang med par mi 'gyur bar go dgos te ston pa nyid kyis shes bya'i rnam pa mngon sum du mdzad nas gsungs pa yin pa rgyu mtshan du byas nas brten pa yod pa zhes sbyar ro/ / kha cig chos sangs rgyas la brten zhes pa tsam dang / de bzhin gshegs pa'i snying po la brten pa zhes sbyar ba ni gzhung 'ga' zhig don slong ma nus pa'o/ /

The word “reliability” in the phrase here should be understood to mean that, when dharma is taken as a reliance, the support given to the one relying on it will not ever change. Then, the dharma is what the teacher spoke after he had produced direct perception of the knowables so, with that as the reason, there are the words “it has reliability”. One person says that the phrase here has to be taken to mean simply “dharma is reliant on buddha” and another says that it means “dharma is reliant on the tathāgata’s compassion”; understand that the meaning supplied here in some texts does not get to the actual meaning[277].

de la 'di snyam du/ de ltar chos de mi bslu ba'i yid brtan rung bar gyur kyang / 'di ltar 'jig rten gyi khams na bya ba bzang po dang 'bras bu bzang po la longs spyod pa thams cad bzang por zad kyang / bzang po mthar phyin te/ da ni 'gyi ba ci'ang med de zhes mtha' gcig tu yid brtan rung ba med pas chos kyang de dang 'dra'o snyam na min te/ chos la brten na bzang po mthar phyin pa'i gnas bya ba byas pa dang / khur bor ba mi slob pa'i 'bras bu la sbyor ba yod de/ de'i tshe na slar yang bya ba gzhan dang gzhan la sbyor ba'am/ gcig nas gcig tu brgyud cing 'gro ba yang dag par chad pas na rgyu ba bcad pa zhes te/

Concerning that, you might have this idea, “Such dharma is suitable to be taken as a non-deceptive mental reliance. However, in a world like this, where all enjoyments reaped in relation to doing good and obtaining a good result are cases of ‘exhaustion in a good result’, but where finalized good, about which it is said that, ‘at this time there is no known activity’, could not be suitable to be taken as an absolute mental reliance, and dharma too must be the same”[278]. However, it is not so. When you rely on dharma, activities done for the sake of a place of finalized good do connect you with the point of laying down the burden, the fruition of nomore-training. When that has been reached, the journeying involved in either having once again to do some other type of activity and connect with something else or having to continue on and on is truly cut, thus it does end the journey[279].
rnam bshad rig pa las/ gong na med pa nyid ni rgyu ba bcad pa nyad kyis te/ ches shin tu mchog tu 'gro ba ni rgyu ba'o/ / de 'dir yang dag par chad pas na rgyu ba bcad pa'o/ / zhes gsungs so/ /

The Vyākhyāyuktī[280] says, Nothing higher[281] itself means that journeying is ended; The travel towards that utterly supreme greatness is journeying. That here has been truly cut thus the journeying is ended.

'di la sems sems byung gi rgyu ba bcad pa dang / 'khor bar 'gro ba bcad pa sogs sna tshogs zhig 'grel pa so so na bshad kyang phyogs re ba ste zur ma phyin pa'o/ / tshig phyi ma 'di gnyis don brling pas gsal por 'di na phye ba kho na'o/ /

Certain commentaries have their own way of explaining how these words should be understood, such as “the movement of mind and mental events is cut” and “migrating about in samsara is cut”, and so on, but those are only partial explanations that do not get to the full meaning. The last two sentences in the quotation just given state the meaning in a way that definitively distinguishes the meaning of this epithet.

de lta na shes bya'i chos kyi khongs 'di na yid brtan 'gyur med du rung ba'i dngos po ni chos kho na yin par shes shing / 'das dang da lta dang ma 'ongs pa'i rgyal ba sras dang slob mar bcas pa dang / 'gro ba'i bde skyid legs lam thams cad chos kyi snang ba kho na las byung bar yid ches nas dam pa'i chos 'dzin pa'i smon lam gdab par bya ste/ de dag tu rgyal ba'i sras kyi smon lam tshad med pa'ang 'du bar mdo las gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

Given all of that and understanding that the only thing within this vault of knowable dharmas that could be cherished as an unchanging mental reliance is dharma, and given that the good paths of happiness of the conquerors of the past, present, and future, together with their sons and disciples, and of all migrators, arise only from the appearance of dharma, we have a need—we must make prayers of aspiration for holding to the holy dharma. This point was taught in the sutras, so prayers like that can be found in an enormous number of the conquerors’ sons’ prayers of aspiration.

de ltar chos kyi yon tan rjes su dran nas da lta dam pa'i chos rin po che'i snang ba 'di dang 'phrad pa re dga' snyam du rang nus dang bstun pa'i chos gzung bar bya ste/ de la'ang byams pas/ yi ge 'bri mchod sbyin pa dang / / nyan dang klog dang len pa dang / / 'chad dang kha ton byed pa dang / / de sems pa dang sgom pa'o/ / zhes pa ltar chos spyod bcu'i tshul gyis nyams su len pas mi tshe don yod pa la 'bad par bya'o/ /

Now that you have recollected the good qualities of the dharma in that way, the next step is to take up the dharma according to your own capacity with the thought, “How joyful I am now that I have met this appearance of the precious dharma”. Maitreya said this about taking up dharma, Copying letters, offering, giving, Hearing, reading, comprehending, Explaining, reciting, Contemplating it, and meditating … which means that you should exert yourself at making this human life meaningful by practice founded in the ten dharma activities that Maitreya mentions[282].
de lta na dam pa'i chos zhes bya ba'i tshigs bcad gcig thos pa dang / gzung ba dang / 'chad pa dang / don sems pa'i phan yon kyang tshad med dpag tu med pa dag rgyas par mdo las shes par bya'o/ /
